Hey Colin,

> Regarding the cat & mouse domain, [...]. This is a variation on 
> the prey capture experiment in the paper "Incremental Evolution Of 
> Complex General Behavior (1997)"

Cheers for the input.  As a matter of fact that paper is one of the
main publications that I am basing my incremental learning design on.
 I pretty much raided Ken's site of research papers over the last
several weeks and was very excited when I came across it.  Some great
reading.  Although not NEAT-specific, another relevant paper on
incremental learning, although unfortunately quite brief, is here:
http://www.debonet.com/Research/Learning/PacMan/

One of my aims was/is to improve upon the existing predator/prey
experiments using neuroevolution by including restrictions on movement
and sight (walls).  It has proven to be quite a dilemma.  I'm working
day and night on this thing and really haven't gotten anywhere in
terms of scenario D (see earlier response to Derek).

Mike

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Colin Green <cgreen@d...> wrote:
> Hi All,
> 
> Firstly I totally agree with Derek's comments regarding not getting too 
> hung up on implementation specifics. If you have the core algorithm 
> running then that should be enough, implemeting all of the details
might 
> improve the efficiency of some searches(it may take less generations to 
> find a solution), but generally speaking it won't greatly effect the 
> ability to find a solution overall.
> 
> Regarding the cat & mouse domain, again I agree with Derek's comment's 
> on the fitness gradient probably being too steep. This is a
variation on 
> the prey capture experiment in the paper "Incremental Evolution Of 
> Complex General Behavior (1997)", which can be found at (beware of URL 
> wrapping):
> 
>
http://nn.cs.utexas.edu/pub-view.php?RECORD_KEY(Pubs)=PubID&PubID(Pubs)=35
> 
> In that domain there is no maze, just a bounded grid space, but
there is 
> a limited sensor range. Therefore if the prey goes out of sensor range 
> then the agent must use memory in order to move in the correct 
> direction. The paper describes how this was too big a problem to solve 
> directly. Instead, an agent is evolved on progressively more difficult 
> tasks whereby the prey is given an increasing number of 'head start' 
> moves, thus allowing it to move out of sensor range before the agent is 
> allowed to move. To further increase the difficulty the prey's speed is 
> increased from stationary up to a maximum of 1 move per timestep, which 
> is the same as the agent's speed. The prey moves stochastically, so a 
> speed of 0.5 means that it has a 50% chance of moving in a given
timestep.
> 
> The paper in question didn't use NEAT but I have implemented it in 
> SharpNEAT and it works very well, although I have never evolved a 
> perfect network. Typically the best that I have achieved after some 
> tweaking of the evaluation function has been a 1/1000 fail rate, which 
> is pretty good really.
> 
> Colin
